questions.question: According to the APA Division 12 Task Force standards discussed in Lesson 1, what is a requirement for a therapy to be classified as 'Efficacious'?
options: It must be superior to a waitlist control group in at least two independent settings.
It must be superior to a pill or psychological placebo or to another bona fide treatment in at least two independent settings.
It must have a minimum of 500 peer-reviewed case studies published in the last decade.
It must be practiced by at least 10,000 certified clinicians worldwide.
questions.explanation: To be classified as 'Efficacious' (the highest standard), a treatment must be shown to be superior to a placebo or another established treatment in at least two high-quality independent research trials.

questions.question: The T.A.P.P.I.N.G. Methodâ„¢ primarily modulates the 'threat-detection' center of the brain. Which structure is most directly inhibited during acupoint stimulation?
questions.explanation: fMRI and EEG studies show that tapping on acupoints sends a calming signal to the amygdala, down-regulating the body's fight-or-flight response even while the stressor is being recalled.

questions.question: In the landmark 2016 study by Church et al. on epigenetics, a single 60-minute EFT session was found to significantly modulate the expression of how many genes?
questions.explanation: The study found that one hour of EFT significantly altered the expression of 72 genes, including those involved in the suppression of cancer tumors and the regulation of the immune system.

questions.question: Meta-analyses of EFT for depression (e.g., Nelms & Castel, 2016) have reported an 'Effect Size' (Cohen's d) that is generally categorized as:
questions.explanation: Meta-analyses consistently show that EFT has a 'Large' effect size (often exceeding 0.8) for depression, meaning the magnitude of improvement is significant compared to standard care.

questions.question: Research involving veterans with PTSD (Church et al., 2013) demonstrated that what percentage of participants no longer met clinical criteria for PTSD after six 1-hour EFT sessions?
questions.explanation: 90% of the veterans in the EFT group were no longer clinical for PTSD after just six sessions, compared to only 4% in the waitlist control group.

questions.question: In the 2020 cortisol replication study by Stapleton et al., EFT resulted in a ____ reduction in salivary cortisol levels, significantly outperforming the psychoeducation group.
questions.explanation: The study found a 37% reduction in cortisol levels after one hour of EFT, which was more than double the reduction seen in the group receiving standard talk therapy/education (14%).

questions.question: Longitudinal studies on EFT for weight management and food cravings (Stapleton et al., 2012; 2016) are unique because they show that:
options: Participants regain all weight within 3 months.
Results are only effective if the person continues tapping 5 hours a day.
Cravings remain reduced or continue to improve at the 12-month follow-up.
EFT only works for sweet cravings, not savory ones.
questions.explanation: Unlike many weight loss interventions, EFT studies show that the reduction in food cravings and associated weight loss are maintained or even improve at one-year follow-up intervals.

questions.question: Implementing Evidence-Based Practice (EBP) requires the integration of three pillars. These are: Best Research Evidence, Patient Values/Preferences, and:
questions.explanation: The EBP triad is the integration of clinical expertise/judgment, the best available research evidence, and the unique values and preferences of the client.

questions.question: What does an increase in Heart Rate Variability (HRV) typically signify during an EFT session?
options: Improved autonomic nervous system balance and parasympathetic 'tone'
The client is becoming more anxious
questions.explanation: Higher HRV is a marker of a healthy, resilient autonomic nervous system and indicates that the body has shifted from a 'fight or flight' state to a 'rest and digest' state.

questions.question: Which concept explains why EFT can 'neutralize' a traumatic memory without the need for years of talk therapy?
questions.explanation: By stimulating acupoints while focusing on a traumatic memory, EFT interrupts the reconsolidation of the fear response, essentially 'unpairing' the memory from the physiological stress signal.
